thread.title: Missing Malaysia Airlines jet MH370 labeled 'mass murder' by air expert as new evidence revealed
thread.title_full: Missing Malaysia Airlines jet MH370 labeled 'mass murder' by air expert as new evidence revealed

author: Hayley Minn
title: Missing Malaysia Airlines jet MH370 labeled 'mass murder' by air expert as new evidence revealed
text:
Missing Malaysia Airlines jet MH370 labeled 'mass murder' by air expert as new evidence revealed This Morning investigated the mystery of the missing Boeing 777 Share Click   Air expert claims missing MH370 was mass murder Share this video   Thank you for subscribing!   
An air expert has claimed missing Malaysia Airlines jet MH370 was a mass murder by the pilot Captain Zaharie Ahmad Shah, three years after the plane disappeared. 
The Boeing 777 disappeared on its way from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing in March 2014 with 239 passengers and crew on board, sparking a two-and-a-half year search that focused on the Indian Ocean. 
Authorities from Malaysia, Australia and China initially expected to finish searching a 120,000 sq km (46,000 sq mile) target area by the end of 2016 but bad weather delayed the probe by another two months back in January, and brought it to an end. 
However, on This Morning, journalist Mark Williams-Thomas investigated further into the mystery. Flight MH370 went missing three years ago (Photo: ITV) Air expert insists it was mass murder (Photo: ITV) Captain Zaharie Ahmad Shah has been accused of "mass murder" A Malaysia Airlines plane (Photo: Getty) 
One of the plane’s wings was found in Reunion Island 3000 miles away from the search area, “in an extended position that only a pilot could’ve done”, meaning the plane was brought down intentionally. 
And air expert Larry Vance confessed he believes the pilot is a culprit of mass murder. 
He added: “There’s no other explanation for it. 
“One of the pilots landed it intentionally on the water so it would sink and would never be seen again.” 
As Mark went into a simulator to see what would’ve happened on the plane, he revealed even more disturbing news. 
A pilot said: “The impact on the water would be survivable - which we’ve seen from Sully. (Photo: ITV) (Photo: ITV) 
“The pilot may have turned off oxygen in the cabin before landing and put on his own oxygen mask.” 
Speaking to Phillip Schofield and Holly Willoughby, Mark explained this means we don’t know what happened to the pilot. 
He added: “Did he commit suicide or survive? We don’t know!” 
*This Morning continues on ITV1 weekdays at 10.30am Like us on Facebook
